description: From the Latin innuendō (“by nodding”), ablative singular form of innuendum (“a nodding”), gerund of innuō (“I give a nod”).

nouns.description: innuendo (plural innuendoes or innuendos or innuendis)

entries.meaning: A derogatory hint or reference to a person or thing. An implication, intimation or insinuation.
examples: She made a devious innuendo about her husband, who was embarrassed.

entries.meaning: (logic) A rhetorical device with an omitted, but obvious conclusion, made to increase the force of an argument.
(law) Part of a pleading in cases of libel and slander, pointing out what and who was meant by the libellous matter or description.

verbs.description: innuendo (third-person singular simple present innuendos, present participle innuendoing, simple past and past participle innuendoed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To interpret (something libellous or slanderous) in terms of what was implied.
examples: A statement that a person's presence at a certain club may be "irksome," may be innuendoed that the person is of such bad character as not to be a fit associate with honourable men.
